strInstructions: Squeeze lime over chicken and rub well. Drain off excess lime juice. Combine tomato, scallion, onion, garlic, pepper, thyme, pimento and soy sauce in a large bowl with the chicken pieces. Cover and marinate at least one hour. Heat oil in a dutch pot or large saucepan. Shake off the seasonings as you remove each piece of chicken from the marinade. Reserve the marinade for sauce. Lightly brown the chicken a few pieces at a time in very hot oil. Place browned chicken pieces on a plate to rest while you brown the remaining pieces. Drain off excess oil and return the chicken to the pan. Pour the marinade over the chicken and add the carrots. Stir and cook over medium heat for 10 minutes. Then add enough water to fully cover the chicken. Cover the pot and simmer until the meat is tender and fully cooked. This should take about 30 minutes. Combine flour and curry powder with about 1/4 cup water. Mix well. Pour into the stewing chicken and stir well to blend. Continue cooking for about 5 more minutes and turn off stove. Enjoy your Brown Stew Chicken with a side of white rice or Jamaican rice and peas.

Preheat oven to 350° F. Spray a 9x13-inch baking pan with non-stick spray. Combine soy sauce, ½ cup water, brown sugar, ginger and garlic in a small saucepan and cover. Bring to a boil over medium heat. Remove lid and cook for one minute once boiling. Meanwhile, stir together the corn starch and 2 tablespoons of water in a separate dish until smooth. Once sauce is boiling, add mixture to the saucepan and stir to combine. Cook until the sauce starts to thicken then remove from heat. Place the chicken breasts in the prepared pan. Pour one cup of the sauce over top of chicken. Place chicken in oven and bake 35 minutes or until cooked through. Remove from oven and shred chicken in the dish using two forks. *Meanwhile, steam or cook the vegetables according to package directions. Return the shredded chicken to the pan and add most of the sauce, reserving a bit to drizzle over the top when serving. Add in the cooked vegetables and rice. Stir to combine. Return to oven and cook 15 minutes. Remove from oven and let stand 5 minutes before serving. Drizzle each serving with remaining sauce. Enjoy!

strMeal: Beef Banh Mi Bowls with Sriracha Mayo
strInstructions: Add water to a large pot and bring to a boil. Once water is boiling, add rice noodles and boil for 3-5 minutes. Drain and rinse with cold water. Set aside. Cook ground beef in a large skillet over medium high heat. Add garlic and ginger, and cook for 1-2 minutes. Add fish sauce, soy sauce, and brown sugar, and cook for another minute. Stir in carrots, cilantro, and basil. Mix well. Divide noodles among four bowls. Top with beef mixture, pickled vegetables, jalapeños, and fresh cilantro. Serve immediately with Sriracha Mayo.

Heat the flat grill plate over a low heat, on top of 2 rings/flames if it fits, and brush sparingly with light olive oil. Cook the sausages first. Add the sausages to the hot grill plate/the coolest part if there is one and allow to cook slowly for about 15-20 minutes, turning occasionally, until golden. After the first 10 minutes, increase the heat to medium before beginning to cook the other ingredients. If the grill plate is hot enough, you should hear a gentle sizzle from each ingredient as it's placed on the grill. Fry the bacon for 2-3 minutes on each side. Fry the mushrooms for 3-4 minutes on each side, until nicely golden. Fry the tomatoes for 2-3 minutes on each side. Finally, fry the eggs to your liking. Serve with hot buttered toast and enjoy!

Heat the oil in a large saucepan. Use kitchen scissors to snip the bacon into small pieces, or use a sharp knife to chop it on a chopping board. Add the bacon to the pan and cook for just a few mins until starting to turn golden. Add the onion, celery and carrot, and cook over a medium heat for 5 mins, stirring occasionally, until softened. Add the garlic and cook for 1 min, then tip in the mince and cook, stirring and breaking it up with a wooden spoon, for about 6 mins until browned all over. Stir the tomato purée into the mince, then add the chopped tomatoes. Fill each can half full with water to rinse out any tomatoes left in the can, and add to the pan. Add the honey and season to taste. Simmer for 20 mins. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. To assemble the lasagne, ladle a little of the ragu sauce into the bottom of the roasting tin or casserole dish, spreading the sauce all over the base. Place 2 sheets of lasagne on top of the sauce overlapping to make it fit, then repeat with more sauce and another layer of pasta. Repeat with a further 2 layers of sauce and pasta, finishing with a layer of pasta. To make the white sauce, melt the butter in a saucepan, stir in the plain flour and cook for 2 mins. Slowly whisk in the milk, then bring to the boil, stirring. Turn down the heat and simmer for a few mins, whisking all the time, until thickened and smooth. Season to taste, then stir in half the Parmesan. Pour the white sauce over the pasta, making sure the whole surface is covered, right to the edges of the dish. Scatter over the remaining Parmesan and cherry tomatoes. Bake for 25-30 mins until golden and bubbling. Serve scattered with basil, if you like.

Cooking in a cajun spice and cayenne pepper marinade makes this fish super succulent and flavoursome. Top with a zesty dressing and serve in a tortilla for a quick, fuss-free main. Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Scatter the cajun spice and cayenne pepper onto a plate with a pinch of salt. Press the fish into the spices on both sides, then place on a baking tray. Bake for 10-12 mins until the fish flakes easily. Meanwhile, mix the mayonnaise, yogurt and lime juice together. Serve the fish in the middle of the table with the tortillas, slaw, avocado, coriander and yogurt dressing, and let everyone help themselves.

Preheat the oven to 200C/180C Fan/Gas 6. Put the biscuits in a large re-usable freezer bag and bash with a rolling pin into fine crumbs. Melt the butter in a small pan, then add the biscuit crumbs and stir until coated with butter. Tip into the tart tin and, using the back of a spoon, press over the base and sides of the tin to give an even layer. Chill in the fridge while you make the filling. Cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. You can do this in a food processor if you have one. Process for 2-3 minutes. Mix in the eggs, then add the ground almonds and almond extract and blend until well combined. Peel the apples, and cut thin slices of apple. Do this at the last minute to prevent the apple going brown. Arrange the slices over the biscuit base. Spread the frangipane filling evenly on top. Level the surface and sprinkle with the flaked almonds. Bake for 20-25 minutes until golden-brown and set. Leave to cool for 15 minutes before removing the sides of the tin. An easy way to do this is to stand the tin on a can of beans and push down gently on the edges of the tin. Serve warm with cream, crème fraiche or ice cream.

Wash and soak toor dal in approx. 3 cups of water, for at least one hours. Dal will be double in volume after soaking. Drain the water. Cook dal with 2-1/2 cups water and add salt, turmeric, on medium high heat, until soft in texture (approximately 30 mins) it should be like thick soup. In a frying pan, heat the ghee. Add cumin seeds, and mustard seeds. After the seeds crack, add bay leaves, green chillies, ginger and chilli powder. Stir for a few seconds. Add the onions, salt and sugar stir and fry until the onions are golden brown. Add the tomatoes and mix it well. Cook until tomatoes are tender and mushy. Add cilantro and mix it well. Serve with Naan or Chawal.

Grind the cashew, poppy seeds and cumin seeds into a smooth paste, using very little water. Set aside. Gently heat the milk and dissolve the saffron in it. Set aside. Wash the rice and soak in water for twenty minutes. Heat the ghee in a pan and fry the onions until dark brown. Drain on paper towels, cool, and crush coarsely. Return the ghee to the heat and fry the cashew-cumin-poppy seed paste until richly browned. Add the meat, yoghurt, garlic paste, green chillies, ginger, chilli powder, garam masala, half the fried crushed onions, the coriander, mint, salt and lemon juice. Mix and allow to simmer gently until the meat is three-quarters done. Parboil the rice in plenty of water until three-quarters cooked. It should still have a little bite to it in the centre. Drain well – reserving the water. Heat a little ghee in a small pan and add the bay leaves, cloves, cardamoms, cinnamon and mace, and pour over the rice. Stir. Brush a little ghee over the bottom of a heavy pan and place a layer of rice in it. Add a layer of meat, then more rice, a sprinkling of the saffron-infused milk, the remaining onions, more rice, and the rest of the meat. Cover with the remaining rice and sprinkle over the remaining saffron milk and ghee. Cover the pan with foil, then with the lid, sealing well so no steam escapes. Cook on a high heat for five minutes, then reduce the heat to very low and cook for 35-40 minutes. To serve, gently mix the rice and lamb together, taking care not to break the grains of rice.

Preheat the oven to 200°C/fan180°C/gas 6. fry sausages in a non-stick pan until browned. Drain and leave to cool. To make the batter, put the flour, mustard powder and a pinch of salt in a bowl and make a well in the middle. Crack in the eggs and add a splash of milk then stir with a wooden spoon, gradually drawing in flour from the sides. Add more milk as you go until you get a smooth batter. Put the vegetable oil in a 1.5 litre ovenproof dish and heat in the oven for 10 minutes. Add the sausages to the hot oil and pour over the batter. Top with cherry tomatoes if you like and return to the oven for 30 minutes until puffed up and golden brown. Serve with green veg and gravy.

Put the flour, eggs, milk, 1 tbsp oil and a pinch of salt into a bowl or large jug, then whisk to a smooth batter. Set aside for 30 mins to rest if you have time, or start cooking straight away. Set a medium frying pan or crêpe pan over a medium heat and carefully wipe it with some oiled kitchen paper. When hot, cook your pancakes for 1 min on each side until golden, keeping them warm in a low oven as you go. Serve with lemon wedges and caster sugar, or your favourite filling. Once cold, you can layer the pancakes between baking parchment, then wrap in cling film and freeze for up to 2 months.

In a wok add chicken broth and wait for it to boil. Next add salt, sugar, white pepper, sesame seed oil. When the chicken broth is boiling add the vegetables to the wok. To thicken the sauce, whisk together 1 Tablespoon of cornstarch and 2 Tablespoon of water in a bowl and slowly add to your soup until it's the right thickness. Next, slowly pour in the beaten eggs constantly stirring so they become more of a ribbon texture in the soup. Serve immediately.
